awd_titl_txt: Phosphatase Control of Collective Cell Migration during Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells move and migrate to new locations in the bodies of developing animals, an important step for the correct formation and function of organs. The proposed research uses a simple genetic model, the fruit fly, to investigate how cells move as organized groups within the animal. The overall goal of these studies is to identify fundamental mechanisms that keep cells together during cell movement, a poorly understood process. Results from these studies are expected to shed light on the way that cells migrate to populate tissues and organs during animal development. A major impact of the proposed project is the training of students and encouragement of underrepresented groups to pursue scientific-intensive careers. Because of the ease of use and available genetic tools, these studies with the fruit fly model are ideally suited for the training of students. The McDonald lab has a history of training undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds, and will continue to do so in the proposed studies. The investigator will specifically recruit female and underrepresented minority undergraduate students from three local institutions that currently offer limited research opportunities. The project also includes several outreach efforts, based on the proposed research, to a local grade school and high school comprised mainly of underrepresented minorities. These activities together will introduce students to research in genetics and animal cell and developmental biology and encourage them to pursue scientific and technical careers.

Throughout development cells frequently move in groups to form, shape and remodel tissues and organs. Such "collectively" migrating cells adhere strongly to one another but also coordinate movement of the whole group as a single unit. Despite their crucial importance to development, how cells migrate collectively rather than individually remains poorly characterized. Drosophila border cells represent a genetically accessible model for the discovery of fundamental regulatory pathways that underlie collective cell movement. Dynamic cycles of phosphorylation and dephosphorylation regulate the cellular signaling pathways and physical/cytoskeletal dynamics involved in individual and collective cell migration. While the functions of protein kinases are well established, much less is known about the roles of protein phosphatases. Novel preliminary data indicate that protein phosphatase activity is an unanticipated controller of collective cohesion and migration of border cells. Border cells in which phosphatase activity is inhibited round up, break off from the main group and are unable to complete their migration. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that distinct phosphatase complexes maintain a collective mode of migration through dynamic regulation of identifiable substrates. The proposed project combines genetic, live imaging, cell biology and biochemical approaches to determine which phosphatase complexes regulate collective border cell migration. Moreover, these studies will identify phosphatase target proteins responsible for the collective cohesion and migration of border cells. As common mechanisms underlie different collective cell migration processes, the proposed studies utilizing the powerful border cell model will uncover new cellular and molecular pathways regulated by protein phosphatases. Together, this will critically advance knowledge of how organs form and are remodeled by collectives during development of multicellular organisms.

por.por_cntn:
Cells within the body often move in small to large groups termed "collectives." These collective cell movements are critical for the formation of tissues and organs during the development of animal embryos. All cells in a collective need to stay together and coordinate their individual movements so that the group as a whole makes the journey to its ultimate destination. How cells migrate in collectives rather than as single cells, especially inside complex embryos, is still poorly understood. This project used the fairly simple organism, Drosophila melanogaster (the common fruit fly), to discover biochemical and genetic pathways that keep cells together as they migrate inside a developing organ. The overall goal of this project was to determine how protein phosphatases, specifically the Protein phosphatase 1 (Pp1) class of phosphatases, promotes collective cell migration using the Drosophila model.

We found that Pp1 keeps "border cells" together while they move as a cluster within the developing Drosophila ovary. Pp1 maintains attachments between border cells so they stay in a group and, through the cellular cytoskeleton, controls shape and movement of these cells. A key to how Pp1 works in these cells is by binding to other proteins called "regulatory subunits." We identified at least one regulatory subunit, the Myosin binding subunit (Mbs) that works with Pp1 to control cytoskeleton organization. We discovered another protein, Rap1 (a small GTPase), that strengthens attachments between border cells and helps border cells keep their shape while migrating. Finally, we showed that one cytoskeletal target of Pp1, non-muscle Myosin II, maintains the overall shape of the border cell cluster. This in turn helps the border cells to navigate successfully through the ovary. These discoveries together reveal how single cells join together, keep their shapes, and move within complex developing organs. The identified proteins are present in a vast range of animals, including mammals such as humans. Thus, our findings apply broadly to other cell types that migrate collectively.

The broader impact goals of this project were: firstly, to encourage students from historically underrepresented groups to pursue scientific research and careers; and secondly, to communicate our research to the general public through outreach efforts. In the first goal, we successfully trained 10 undergraduate research students in the lab, including 8 women and 5 students from underrepresented groups. Three graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow participated in this project and trained the undergraduate students, thus enhancing their own teaching skills and professional development. All undergraduate students presented their research at local, regional, and national scientific conferences. As a sign of success, these undergraduate students are currently finishing college or have graduated and gone on to scientific and medically related professional education and careers. In the second goal, we engaged in multiple community outreach endeavors. These included a public talk to the local community, booths at multiple local scientific outreach events, a video created by a journalism student describing our research, and two hands-on scientific workshops for 6th-12th grade girls. We also contributed multiple scientific images that were highlighted in regional and national contests, with two images selected for printed calendars. Along with our publications, these activities disseminated our research to the general public.
